title: Woman's bathroom is likened to a 'murder scene' after she scrubbed the tiles
text:
A mother has been left with a bathroom that looks like a 'murder scene' after combining two strong cleaning products that eroded the paint on her shower tiles.

The Australian woman posted about her mistake in the Mums Who Clean Facebook group, saying that she used commercial bleach and Windex 'all the time' on the area and had 'never had any problems' before.

'I cleaned the tiles in the shower and now they look like this. What is it and how can I remove it? I've scrubbed but it won't budge,' she said.

An overzealous cleaner has been left with a bathroom that looks like a 'murder scene' after combining two strong cleaning products and eroding the paint on her shower tiles

Why should you never mix ammonia and bleach together? Bleach and ammonia produce a toxic gas called chloramine. It causes the same symptoms as bleach and vinegar (burning eyes, coughing) - along with shortness of breath and chest pain. Many glass and window cleaners contain ammonia, so never mix those with bleach. To clean shower grout correctly it's best to mix 3/4 cup household chlorine bleach with 3.5 litres of water. Wearing rubber gloves and eye protection, use a stiff brush to apply the formula to one small area at a time. Be careful not to let the liquid spatter onto surrounding surfaces. Let it sit for several minutes, then scrub and rinse. Source: Good Housekeeping

She received a flurry of messages from concerned women who said it looked 'burnt' and 'like rust'.

While many weren't sure what damage had been done, some believed that the ammonia found in Windex reacted with the bleach to strip away the old paint on the tiles and form a toxic gas.

'It's a really dangerous combination if they happen to come into contact with each other,' one person wrote.

BEFORE: While many weren't sure what damage had been done, some believed the bleach and ammonia found in Windex reacted to strip away the old paint on the tiles

AFTER: The older orange tiles with a red floral print had been reduced to a blood-like stain that ran down the wall and along the floor

One woman she had seen the same thing happen in her own bathroom with tiles of a similar age.

'I used bleach and let it sit longer than planned and it did this to the printed tiles,' she said.

'Eventually it lightened and went away but it took time... nothing could get it off because it was soaked into the tiles.'

Other group members were suggesting she paint over the tiles with a different colour or use gumption to clear up the messy remains.

authors: Matilda Rudd For Daily Mail Australia
